Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as a670091344f473514eb059ea0824ad8ede707372
Please add newly added plugging output details ( file name and size) , good for reference.
-e option is used to check if the file is exist ,  not for running.?
Yes we are checking existence of file, will change the comment content from "running" to "enabled"
Have changed the logic, we only need to collect data when LDAP is enabled. Please review new patch.

This will additional overhead of 5 second for every dump collection. There is big push on reducing the Dump collection time. I am not an expert in user manager area. Please look any alternative like during dump collction , just copy the file instead of waiting or optimize this delay logic , by reducing interval based aproch.,
I got your concern that a 5 sec delay will additional overhead for every dump, but we are creating this file at run time so for safer side we are keeping 5 sec delay to collect all required data.
please pull /etc/nslcd.conf file into  bmc dump

Avoid usage of camel case type variable name. 
open_ldap_command

This should create problem , incase multiple dumps packaging happening parallely.
use dump specific path .

/var/lib/ path also parallely used by dump-manager right?
can we keep this file at /var/lib/phosphor-debug-collector/dumps?

/var/lib/phosphor-debug-collector/dumps is not intended to use temporary data. you can use the logic similair to https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/blob/master/tools/dreport.d/dreport#L194 in /tmp path . basically need unique path for this particular dump
Updated code as per the suggestion.

why we are not taking the dump of the whole object? why specific property?
Ignore the password from the dump.
We are collecting minimum data which is required to analyse LDAP data.
This is still not fixing the issue i mentioned earlier , Not a unique file name incase multiple dump is in progress.

Is a unique file needed for each dump request? 
I think the idea is to collect the latest data at the time when the dump is gathered. The next dump will collect the updated file.

Refer https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/68090/5..9/tools/dreport.d/plugins.d/ldapdump#b34.
As mentioned incase multipe dumps running in same context , possible chamce deleting same file , by dreport plugs. to avoid this recommended unique file name based approch ( open bmc extensively uses this ) .

https://www.cyberciti.biz/tips/shell-scripting-bash-how-to-create-temporary-random-file-name.html

#!/bin/bash
#do init some stuff here
 
#now make a temp file 
TMP_FILE=$(mktemp -q /tmp/bar.XXXXXX)
if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then
    echo "$0: Can't create temp file, bye.."
    exit 1
fi
 
#continue with script
echo "Using $TMP_FILE ..."
Seems in this file, Password is there, You need to make sure that user credentials should not be there.

NSLCD stores passwords in plain text only, we are just collecting data.
We can create a defect against nslcd to handle the plain text password and store password in some non-readable/encrypted format.
This seems to be a security violation right ?  I think we should hold the change to coping conf file till the  security problem fixed ?.
Yes it is a security violation, But why can't we take dump of other content from this file except password?

Hi Ratan/Jayanth
user credentials are not stored in this file, nslcd only stores bind password of ldap server in file

here we are talking about "bindpw" field, so can we mark password with some <hidden> text with the help of 'sed' utility before collecting it to dump.
it will look like this in dump.
   bindpw <hidden>
will this work?

for this we need to first collect all nslcd.conf content in a temp file, then will modify temp file content for bindpw field with 'sed' utility
       sed -i 's/^bindpw .*/bindpw <hidden>/' /tmp/nslcd 
and then will store temp file data to dump.

This does not look like a security violation, otherwise storing bind password in nslcd Configuration file on BMC also considered as security violation right?
as far as I remember from earlier discussions storing bind passoword in nslcd configuration file was not considered as security violation where as user credentials password was encrypted and stored for ipmi user-cases.
Including @Joseph to comment from OpenBMC Security

I am not an LDAP expert, so please correct any mistakes.
The nslcd.conf options binddn and bindpw store optionally-provided credentials the BMC uses to authenticate to the LDAP server.  (Ideally these credentials will give read-only access to the LDAP server, but that is beyond the scope of the BMC.). The credentials are stored in plaintext in this file, and the file is protected by Linux file system permissions so only the root user is allowed to read and write.
In this way, the file has appropriate access controls while it is on the BMC.

If this file is included in a dump, it would contain the LDAP credentials, which would disclose the credentials to anyone who has read access to the dump.  Is that only BMC admin users, or would the dump be distributed to less trustworthy people?  And do they already have access to this information?  [I'm not sure what the answer is.]

Assuming most of the time we don't need the value of these options, obscuring them (such as with the sed command above) seems like a good compromise of getting the dump we need and not disclosing the credentials.
ok then, lets avoid displaying binddn option including password in the file

Decided to not include "bindpw" entry instead of hiding/encrypt "bindpw" value.
Update code. Please review.
This directory should hold the othe ldap config files, right incase , any other dump is in progress? shouldn't be deleting this file.
Yes, we should not delete it. Updated code. Please review.
If the directory is not present you should create one,

Nit : better to resture the below , will help for debug why ldap data is not present.

if [ "$ldapEnabled" == "false" ]; then
 log_warning "skipping LDAP dump:  LDAP is not enabled"
 exit 0;
fi.

Then you can continue the dump collection
How this output looks for line 30 command ? just make sure the readabilty is good here.

it will look like this:

=============busctl call  xyz.openbmc_project.Ldap.Config         /xyz/openbmc_project/user/ldap         org.freedesktop.DBus.ObjectManager         'GetManagedObjects'=============

with some extra space(5 blank spaces) only, somehow it is not coming in comment properly.

Code looking good now . Thanks for adding the plugin, which helps the LDAP related issues debug. 
Please work with Ratan/Security team on addressing the security issue Ratan raised.
Seems okay to me, except for concerns about disclosing the binddn and bindpw credentials.  I this the dump function should redact the values of these fields.

Are locked into the bash shell?  I thought we were supposed to be neutral, and write shell scripts that work with both the Bourne shell and with the bash shell.  In particular, this script uses bash-isms such as $(command) instead of the more portable backquotes: `command`.
I believe some BMC users do not have the bash shell installed because of licensing concerns and they use the Bourne shell instead, so they would not be able to use this script.  (But I don't know if that is a concern here, so feel free to ignore this comment.)
Keeping bash shell as all other places we are following the same.

Several comments:
1. The pattern provided to sed ought to match bindpw only when it appears at the beginning of the line, like sed /^bindpw/d.  Otherwise the command may delete lines it did not intend to delete.  Please add the '^' character.

2. I think setting the shell variable this way will mash all the lines together into a single unreadable line.  You may need to use a temporary file to preserve newlines.

3. I would prefer that the dump indicate that the "bindpw" line was present in the original file as it existed on the BMC, but its value was redacted in the dump.  Otherwise folks reading the dump may be confused why this line is missing.  But I am okay with simply deleting this line.
Oops.  Never mind about comment 2 above.  The quotes you have in your code will preserve the newlines.

Updated code to remove line only when it starts with "bindpw".
Earlier, I checked with a sample program to see if we are able to preserve newlines or not. It was working fine for the sample program, but somehow the newlines were not preserved in the dump collection.
Now with the new code changes, newlines are preserved in dump collection.

Why you are using ^bindpw ? should be '/bindpw/d' ?

With this changes , file contains bindpw line.

root@xxxxx:/tmp# cat obmcdump_00000000_1708958634/nslcd.conf | grep bindpw
 Note that if you set a bindpw you should check the permissions of this file.
bindpw secret

i have checked output of the final file, it is removing bindpw line properly.

The reason for using ^bindpw is as follows:
The pattern provided to sed ought to match bindpw only when it appears at the beginning of the line, like sed /^bindpw/d. Otherwise the command may delete lines it did not intend to delete. 

by using ^bindpw we are checking, if a line starts with "bindpw" then we remove that paritcular entry otherwise not.
Sorry , in my verification, i forgot to remove #. That created all the confusion. Thanks for the clarification
Can you please merge this commit?
